awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Molecular Mechanisms of Astrocyte Neuron Interactions in the Development of Synchronous Activity in Neuronal Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
Brain cells are of two types. Neurons are the most well-known; they communicate with each other by generating spikes of electrical activity. The second cell type, glial cells, play a variety of roles that are less well understood. In the awake adult brain, the overall spiking activity of neurons appears random. However, in deep sleep or under anesthesia, the spiking activity pattern becomes synchronized within and between various brain regions. During brain development, this type of synchronous spiking is thought to be necessary for the circuit maturation, and the establishment and maintenance of the functional organization of the brain. The focus of this research is to understand the role of one type of glial cell (astrocytes) in the emergence of synchronous spiking activity patterns in the developing brain. The main hypothesis is that astrocytes play a decisive role in the synchronization of neuronal activity in the brain. Preliminary data has demonstrated that astrocytes are necessary for synchronization of spiking activity; the proposed research will elucidate the molecular pathways within astrocytes that control the synchronization of spiking in surrounding neurons. The results of this research will identify fundamental mechanisms of astrocyte-neuron interactions that shape synchronous activity during brain development. This project is conducted at a Historically Black University, and will immerse minority students in cutting edge neuroscience research, and foster peer-mentoring based on interactions between undergraduate and graduate researchers.

Preliminary data using mixed neuron and astrocyte cultures on multi-electrode arrays (MEAs) showed random spiking activity which synchronized over time, in comparison to astrocyte-free neuronal cultures, which only show random activity without synchronization. The main hypothesis of this research is that astrocytic release of glutamate mediated by the mGluR1 G-protein-coupled-receptor (GPCR) pathway mediates the effects of astrocytes on the development of neuronal synchronous activity. A model for the mechanism by which the astrocyte mGluR1 pathway mediates neuronal synchronization will be tested using several different dominant negative constructs. A dominant-negative mGluR1 receptor that blocks downstream signaling will be used to understand this signaling pathway's role in both population synchrony, and in the temporal relationship between calcium oscillations within astrocytes and the development of neuronal synchronous bursts.  A dominant-negative SNARE protein Vamp2/Syb2 will be used to block glutamate release from astrocytes. The role of the mGluR1 pathway and mGluR1 mediated glutamate release in the development of synchrony will also be examined in vivo. The strength of this project is the combination of multi-electrode electrophysiology, molecular dissection of the mGluR1 pathway in astrocytes, and computational analyses.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The focus of our research is to understand the role of a type of glial cell called astrocyte in the development of synchronous activity in the brain. Nerve cells or neurons communicate with each other by generating action potentials or spikes. In the awake brain the overall spiking activity of the hundred billion neurons appears random. However, when in deep sleep or under anaesthesia, spiking activity becomes synchronized between various regions in the brain. This type of synchronous spiking is necessary for the development and maintenance of the functional organization of the brain. Synchronized spiking activity also occurs during epileptic seizures – epilepsy is currently an intractable disease with no cure. Existing models of synchronous activity assume that it is a process intrinsic to neurons. However, recent studies indicate that astrocytes actively participate in neuronal communication in addition to their supporting role.

The Tripartite synapse

Neurons communicate with each other at specialized junctions called synapses. The communication is electro-chemical – an electrical signal from a pre-synaptic neuron causes chemical transmitter to be released into the synaptic cleft which is sensed by receptors on the post-synaptic neuron and translated into an electrical signal. Traditionally, the synapse was considered to consist of the pre- and post-synaptic neurons only. In the past 20 years, evidence that the synapse is not just between neurons and that astrocytes are also present at the synapse and communicate with both the pre- and post-synaptic neurons has steadily accumulated. The tripartite synapse originally proposed by Dr. Phil Haydon at the University of Pennsylvania is now generally accepted in the neuroscience research community. Astrocytes at the tripartite synapse not only sense the neurotransmitter released by the pre-synaptic neuron but also release their own chemicals – called gliotransmitters.

Preliminary results from our laboratory indicated that astrocytes are necessary for the synchronization of neuronal network activity. Using the developing chick embryo brain as our model system, we established pure neuronal cultures in the absence of glial cells by adding 5 flurodeoxyuridine (FUdR) a drug which kills the dividing astrocytes but spares the non-dividing neurons. We ensured survival of the neurons by supplementing the cultures with astrocyte conditioned medium which contains the necessary nutrients for neurons to survive (Figure 1). We demonstrated that neurons in the absence of astrocytes have a lower overall network activity and cannot synchronize.

Model for astrocyte role in neuronal synchrony development

The central hypothesis that drives our research is that astrocytes play a central role in the synchronization of neurons in the brain. We also hypothesized that activation of a type of receptor called the metabotropic glutamate receptor (mGluR) in astrocytes and its downstream signalling pathway culminating in an increased calcium flux plays an important role in synchronizing neuronal spiking activity. This is depicted in our proposed model which is based on the tripartite synapse (Figure 2).

In this project we set out to test our hypothesis with a molecular approach – we blocked the mGluR pathway in astrocytes using a dominant negative approach – a truncated version of the mGluR receptor protein when expressed in astrocytes blocks the function of the endogenous receptor. Our results demonstrated that astrocytes infected with a lentivirus that expresses the mGluR DN receptor have severely reduced calcium flux (Figure 3).

Our model predicts (based on the literature) that astrocytes possess the pre-synaptic machinery similar to neurons and can release chemical transmitters (gliptransmitters) like neurons. We predicted that activation of the mGluR pathway and increase in calcium flux would cause the release of glutamate from astrocytes. Using a similar strategy as above, we expressed a dominant negative version of the synaptic protein VAMP2/synaptobrevin in astrocytes and showed that it blocks the release of glutamate by astrocytes (Figure 4).

We had earlier demonstrated that it is possible to culture pure neurons in the absence of glial cells by killing off the glial cells with a mitotic inhibitor (FUdR) and supplementing the medium with a conditioning medium. We can keep the neurons alive long-term and record network activity. We have now been able to re-introduce astrocytes into these pure neuron cultures after removal of FUdR. These re-introduced astrocytes integrate into the neuronal network and we see that the network activity increases along with the return of synchronization in these cultures. To our knowledge, this is the first demonstration of neuronal network activity changing with the removal of astrocytes and returning with their addition. Our work is not complete – we are now ready to test our predictions that the mGluR pathway and the release of glutamate by astrocytes is indeed responsible for the development of synchronous neuronal network activity. We will introduce the mGluR and VAMP2 DN astrocytes (and normal astrocytes) into pure neuron cultures (Figure 5). We predict that normal astrocytes, but not mGluR or VAMP2 DN astrocytes will restore normal network activity.
